Week 5: Final Project & Presentation

Whakatutuki me te Whakaaturanga - Achievement and Showcase

Duration: 4 lessons (50 minutes each) | Year Level: 8

Synthesizing statistical learning into meaningful community problem-solving projects

ğŸ¯ Big Question of the Week

"How can data help solve real problems in our community and Aotearoa?"

WhakatÅhea: Purpose - Using Data for Good

Statistics isn't just about numbers - it's about understanding our world and making it better. In te ao MÄori, knowledge (mÄtauranga) comes with responsibility (takohanga). When we understand patterns in data, we have the power and responsibility to act for the benefit of our whÄnau, our school, and our community.

Key Principle: Manaakitanga through data - using our statistical understanding to care for and support others.

ğŸ† Lesson 5.1: Project Selection & Planning

Focus: Choosing meaningful projects that apply statistical learning to real community issues

Project Showcase Options (15 minutes)

Student Choice: Select one project type that connects to your interests and community

ğŸ‰ Sports Performance Analysis

Question: How can we use data to improve our school sports teams?

  • Analyze local sports team performance data
  • Create performance predictions using probability
  • Design training recommendations based on statistical trends
  • Present to coaches or sports coordinators

Perfect for students passionate about sports and competition

ğŸ˜ï¸ Community Issue Investigation

Question: What does data reveal about challenges in our local area?

  • Survey community about local issues (transport, environment, etc.)
  • Analyze demographic data relevant to the issue
  • Create statistical recommendations for solutions
  • Present to local council or community groups

Great for students who want to make a real difference locally

ğŸŒº Cultural & Social Trends Analysis

Question: How is cultural identity changing in New Zealand?

  • Investigate cultural trends using census data
  • Compare different regions or communities
  • Explore language preservation or cultural practices
  • Present insights about cultural diversity and identity

Ideal for students interested in culture and social change

Project Planning Workshop (25 minutes)

ğŸ“‹ Project Planning Template
Project Definition
  • Main Question: What specific problem are you investigating?
  • Target Audience: Who will benefit from your findings?
  • Data Sources: Where will you get your information?
  • Expected Outcome: What do you hope to discover or recommend?
Statistical Methods
  • Data Collection: Surveys, existing datasets, observations?
  • Analysis Tools: CODAP, Google Sheets, hand calculations?
  • Probability Elements: What predictions will you make?
  • Visual Presentation: Charts, infographics, interactive displays?

Team Formation: Students work in pairs or groups of 3, choosing complementary skills

Resource Allocation: Teacher provides access to datasets, survey tools, and presentation materials

Research & Data Gathering Planning (10 minutes)

Homework Assignment: Begin data collection using ethical and respectful methods

âš–ï¸ Ethical Data Collection Reminders
  • Consent: Always ask permission before collecting data from people
  • Anonymity: Protect people's privacy and identity
  • Cultural Sensitivity: Respect cultural protocols and boundaries
  • Accuracy: Report findings honestly, even if they don't match your expectations

ğŸ” Lesson 5.2: Data Analysis & Statistical Investigation

Focus: Applying all statistical skills learned in the unit to analyze project data

Data Analysis Workshop (35 minutes)

Self-Directed Learning: Groups work on their projects with teacher support

Data Organization Station
  • Clean and organize collected data
  • Identify data types (categorical/numerical)
  • Check for missing or unusual values
  • Create summary statistics
Statistical Analysis Station
  • Calculate means, medians, and modes
  • Identify patterns and trends
  • Create appropriate graphs and charts
  • Look for correlations and relationships
Probability & Prediction Station
  • Make predictions based on trends
  • Calculate probabilities where relevant
  • Consider confidence in predictions
  • Identify limitations of data
ğŸ¯ Key Questions to Guide Analysis
  1. Pattern Recognition: What trends do you see in your data?
  2. Significance Testing: Are the patterns meaningful or could they be random?
  3. Cultural Context: How do your findings relate to cultural or social factors?
  4. Action Items: What recommendations emerge from your analysis?
  5. Limitations: What don't your data tell you? What are the gaps?

Peer Consultation & Feedback (15 minutes)

Statistical Peer Review: Groups share preliminary findings with another group for feedback

Peer Review Protocol:
  1. Data Presentation (3 min): Show your main findings and one key graph
  2. Statistical Questions (2 min): Peers ask about methods and calculations
  3. Feedback & Suggestions (2 min): What could be clearer or more convincing?
  4. Role Swap: Repeat process with groups switching roles

ğŸ¨ Lesson 5.3: Presentation Creation & Practice

Focus: Creating compelling presentations that communicate statistical findings effectively

Presentation Design Workshop (25 minutes)

ğŸ¤ Effective Statistical Communication
Content Structure
  1. Hook (1 min): Start with surprising statistic or compelling question
  2. Context (1 min): Why does this issue matter to our community?
  3. Methods (1 min): How did you collect and analyze data?
  4. Key Findings (3 min): What are your main discoveries?
  5. Recommendations (2 min): What should be done based on your findings?
  6. Questions (2 min): Engage audience in discussion
Visual Design Principles
  • Clear Charts: Large, readable graphs with clear labels
  • Key Statistics: Highlight 2-3 most important numbers
  • Cultural Imagery: Include relevant and respectful cultural elements
  • Call to Action: End with specific, achievable recommendations
  • Backup Data: Have detailed analysis ready for questions

Tools Available: Google Slides, Canva, poster materials, or interactive digital displays

Support: Teacher circulates to provide feedback on statistical accuracy and presentation clarity

Practice Presentations & Peer Coaching (25 minutes)

Rehearsal Structure: Groups practice with constructive peer feedback

Practice Session Format (8 minutes per group):
  1. Full Presentation (5 min): Present to practice audience of 2-3 other groups
  2. Feedback Round (2 min): Audience provides specific suggestions for improvement
  3. Quick Q&A (1 min): Practice handling questions about statistical methods
Feedback Focus Areas:
  • Statistical Clarity: Are the numbers and methods clear?
  • Cultural Sensitivity: Is cultural content respectful and meaningful?
  • Audience Engagement: Does the presentation hold attention?
  • Actionable Outcomes: Are recommendations specific and realistic?

ğŸŒŸ Lesson 5.4: Final Presentations & Celebration

Focus: Showcasing statistical learning and celebrating achievements

ğŸ‰ Statistical Showcase Event

Special Audience: Invite school leadership, whÄnau, or community members to see student work

Format: Mini-conference with multiple presentation sessions

Final Presentations (35 minutes)

Conference Format: Each group presents to the whole class + invited guests

Presentation Schedule (7 groups Ã— 5 minutes each):
  • Sports Analysis Projects: Present findings to PE teachers or coaches
  • Community Issue Projects: Share recommendations with school leadership
  • Cultural Trends Projects: Discuss insights about identity and diversity

Audience Participation: Guests and classmates ask questions and provide feedback on statistical methods and community relevance

Unit Reflection & Celebration (15 minutes)

ğŸ¤” Unit Reflection Questions

Individual Reflection (5 min): Students write responses to:

  • What's the most important thing you learned about statistics this unit?
  • How has your understanding of data in daily life changed?
  • What statistical concept do you still find challenging?
  • How might you use statistical thinking in the future?

Class Discussion (5 min): Share insights and celebrate growth

Cultural Connection (5 min): How does statistical thinking connect to mÄtauranga MÄori and traditional ways of understanding patterns?

Whakatutuki! - Achievement Celebration

Acknowledge every student's growth in statistical thinking and their contributions to understanding community issues through data.

ğŸ“‹ Unit Final Assessment: Statistical Investigation Project

Assessment Overview

Summative Assessment: Complete statistical investigation addressing a real community issue, including data collection, analysis, and presentation of findings with actionable recommendations.

Weight: 40% of unit grade | Due: Final presentation in Week 5

ğŸ¯ Assessment Components & Weightings
Data Collection & Organization (25%)
  • Ethical data gathering methods
  • Appropriate sample sizes
  • Clear data organization
  • Recognition of data limitations
Statistical Analysis (30%)
  • Correct use of statistical measures
  • Appropriate graph and chart selection
  • Pattern recognition and trend analysis
  • Probability calculations where relevant
Cultural Integration (20%)
  • Meaningful Te Ao MÄori connections
  • Culturally responsive analysis
  • Respectful use of cultural concepts
  • Community-focused recommendations
Communication & Presentation (25%)
  • Clear, engaging presentation
  • Effective visual communication
  • Response to audience questions
  • Actionable recommendations
ğŸŒŸ Excellence Indicators

Projects achieving Excellence demonstrate:

  • Sophisticated Analysis: Uses advanced statistical concepts creatively and accurately
  • Community Impact: Addresses real issues with realistic, evidence-based solutions
  • Cultural Depth: Shows deep understanding of cultural contexts and their relationship to data
  • Professional Presentation: Communication quality that could influence real decision-makers
  • Statistical Insight: Discovers patterns or connections that weren't immediately obvious
  • Ethical Awareness: Demonstrates sophisticated understanding of responsible data use
â† Week 4: Probability Week 5 of 5 - COMPLETE! Return to Unit Overview

"Whaowhia te kete mÄtauranga - Fill the basket of knowledge"

Statistical learning in service of community

Through this unit, students have learned to see statistics not as abstract numbers, but as powerful tools for understanding and improving their world. By connecting mÄtauranga MÄori with mathematical thinking, they've discovered how data can serve manaakitanga - caring for their communities through informed decision-making.

Kia kaha ki te whakamahi raraunga hei oranga mÅ te katoa!
(Be strong in using data for everyone's wellbeing!)
